University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Signal

Consumer confidence and expectations as a forward demand indicator.

As of 2026-01-01

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Signal is currently Bearish, indicating a demand headwind (1). The latest sentiment level of 51.0 (2025-11-30) reflects a contraction in consumer optimism.
  • Conviction Band: High | Interpretation Confidence: High Confidence | Internal Conflict Flag: No.

Key Dynamics:

  • The sentiment level (UMCSENT) is significantly low with a robust z-score of -1.0829 (1).
  • Momentum is negative, with Year-over-Year change at -28.97% and a three-month change of -12.37%.
  • All quantitative drivers consistently point to a strong demand headwind.
  • Conditional Invalidation: A sustained increase in the Level_z above -0.5, coupled with positive YoY or 3-month momentum.

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant: Consumer sentiment remains Bearish, sustained by negative momentum and low absolute levels.
  • Upside secondary: Sentiment could stabilise if the Level_z improves towards neutral and momentum turns positive.
  • Downside residual: A further decline in sentiment, potentially driven by economic shocks, would deepen the Bearish regime.

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Cyclical (months). Consumer sentiment influences consumption patterns over several months.
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: High. This signal is a primary indicator of household demand and economic outlook.

Macro Relevance:

  • Macro dimension informed: Demand, Sentiment.
  • Cycle position: Suggests a mid-to-late cycle slowdown or contraction phase, where consumer confidence typically wanes.
  • Typical interaction with other macro signals: Often correlates positively with retail sales and industrial production, and negatively with unemployment.

Data & References:

  • University of Michigan: Consumer Sentiment® (UMCSENT) from FRED, latest observation 2025-11-30 (1).
  • The most influential datapoints are the UMCSENT level (51.0), its robust z-score (-1.0829), and the Year-over-Year percentage change (-28.97%).
  • Additional public datasets that would improve depth or reliability include FRED's Retail Sales (RSALES) and Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE).
